oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Confederate Monument on the Court House lawn in Paris

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Monuments; Sculpture; Courthouses; Automobiles; Storefronts
Monuments; Soldiers; Paris (Tenn.); United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Foreground features sculpture of soldier atop base of Confederate Monument honoring Henry County Confederate soldiers. Background shows courthouse lawn, Paris storefronts, and colorful 1950s-1960s era automobiles. Back of card is not filled out. Printed details of the Battle of Paris are present on the back. Item is a patented "C. T. Art-Colortone" linen postcard.

Paris native Governor James D. Porter delivered an address at the unveiling of the Henry County Confederate Monument on Saturday, October 13, 1900. The sculpted figure is referred to as the "Private of '61." It replaced a simple shaft that had previously been mounted on the base. The monument stands on the lawn of the courthouse where Confederate military units organized.
